Details: Two comprehensive Python scripts for Informatica to PySpark migration validation of PS_VENDOR table. Both implement 12-step validation workflows with data extraction, transformation, comparison, and reconciliation. Agent_1_Migration_Script uses more sophisticated error handling with multiple logging handlers and includes API cost tracking. Agent_2_Migration_Script has simpler logging setup but includes more detailed authentication functions. Semantic similarity is high (88/100) with same core purpose and workflow. Structural similarity is good (82/100) with similar function organization but different implementation approaches. Both scripts are syntactically correct (100/100) with proper imports and structure.

Both scripts implement identical core functionality for PS_VENDOR migration validation with same 12-step workflow approach. Key semantic alignments: identical table schema definitions (lines 45-65 in both), same transformation logic with AUD_YR_NBR=2019 and LOAD_DT updates, identical comparison and reconciliation approaches. Minor semantic differences: Agent_1 includes API cost estimation ($0.02) while Agent_2 shows actual cost ($0.012), Agent_1 uses current_timestamp() while Agent_2 uses current_date() for LOAD_DT field, Agent_1 has more detailed GCS integration while Agent_2 focuses more on Databricks authentication.

Both scripts follow identical 12-step structural organization with similar function decomposition. Structural alignments: same configuration section layout, identical schema definition structure, similar main() function flow, consistent error handling patterns. Key structural differences: Agent_1 uses dual logging handlers (StreamHandler + FileHandler, lines 15-22) while Agent_2 uses single file handler (lines 15-18), Agent_1 has more modular GCS functions while Agent_2 has integrated authentication functions, Agent_1 uses pandas+pyarrow for parquet conversion while Agent_2 uses direct pandas.to_parquet(), different variable naming conventions (ELANSURIYAA/AAVA_Testingrt vs report).
